Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Network Economics for Secondary Spectrum Ecosystem

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emerging cognitive radio (CR) technology provides new solutions to the wireless service business. A CR-capable service provider can acquire spectrum on demand from the secondary spectrum market to avoid paying the huge spectrum licensing fees, significantly lowering the threshold of entry to the wireless business. As a result, it is foreseeable that small and local secondary wireless service providers (SSPs) will flourish, transforming the wireless business from one dictated by few giant carriers to a much more competitive marketplace. Existing secondary spectrum market models mainly consider a market comprised by big SSPs, where every SSP is assumed to have sufficient secondary radio resource and coverage to independently service end users. In practice, however, these models inevitably exclude the large number of small and local SSPs that do not have enough resource and coverage to independently satisfy the demand of end users (e.g., for high-rate access or long-range routing) from the market, leading to reduced market competitiveness, and henceforth compromised market efficiency. This project will investigate a novel competition-and-collaboration spectrum market framework, whereby small and local SSPs will collaborate in providing service to retain more market shares, better profitability, stronger market competitiveness, and higher market efficiency. This project, if successful, will significantly advance our understanding on the network economics of the secondary spectrum ecosystem comprised by primary spectrum sellers, SSPs, end users, and human, and will contribute to the real-world deployment of economically feasible and sustainable spectrum market.

The proposed research will follow three thrusts. (1) For short-term services, assuming perfect rationality for every player in the market, the secondary spectrum market is first modeled as a spot market. A truthful procurement auction model is proposed to study the optimal market mechanisms and their strategy proofness under a variety of market conditions. (2) For long-term services, the project will study the potential and implication of the futures market, in which service predictability in the time domain is exploited to improve market efficiency, using methods such as option pricing and hedging. (3) The rational-player assumption is released and the project will study the impact of irrationality and human factors on market efficiency using methods from Behavioral Economics. This project will also carry out a comprehensive educational plan to broaden its impact, including integrating research with undergraduate and graduate education, recruiting and outreaching to minority and under-represented students, and efficient dissemination and outreaching to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Economic perspective has become a common objective for wireless system. The increasing requirement for wireless communication could not bring the spectrum owners the profit when operation cost is high. To determine an efficient spectrum allocation, in recent years, the dynamic allocation of frequency spectrum for wireless applications has been an intensively studied topic in both industry and academia. In such systems, the legacy spectrum owners (also called primary systems) can sell unused spectrum to secondary operators which provide service to their users (also called secondary users) in a secondary market. In this way, the precious resource of spectrum can be efficiently and adaptively utilized, thus significantly increasing the utilization of spectrum, in contrast to the current static allocation of frequency spectrum. The main focus of the study on the dynamic spectrum allocation has been focused on the study of spectrum auction, particularly the mechanism of incentive compatible auction. Various mechanisms such as Vickrey-Clarke-Groves (VCG) mechanism have been studied and adapted to the context of spectrum market. Based on the spectrum auction mechanisms, people have studied the application in wireless communications, e.g., the spectrum sharing in multi-hop networks. In this project, we introduced an extra dimension for the spectrum market following our previous work. We proposed to build a futures market, where the futures contracts for the spectrum are traded. In a futures market, a secondary operator can purchase the right to buy a certain bandwidth of spectrum with a fixed price at a certain future time. For example, the right could be `operator A is allowed to use a 10MHz bandwidth for 1 hour at the price of \$2/Hz beginning from 12pm tomorrow'. Futures market is parallel to the spot market, where the trading is instantaneous. The benefit from the futures market includes (a) Greater Competition. A liquid futures market provides potential new entrants with the vital ability to access competitively priced supply and manage their risk. The result will be a more competitive market. (b) Improved price transparency. The transparent price discovery in futures market could provide greater efficiencies in the wholesale. Existing and new market participants will be able to see the true cost of managing risk. (c) Better risk management. A liquid futures market will provide the spectrum owners with a risk management mechanism to better manage planned maintenance and investment decisions. For simulating the process of spot market price, we have proposed two pricing models and used real measurement data of cellular systems to carry out the numerical simulation. We have found multiple properties for the spot price process, namely the nonlinear volatility and the non-Gaussian price change distribution, thus uncovering the gap between the real price process and the traditional Black-Scholes or Bachlier models. Then, we have studied the pricing mechanism for the options, which is significantly different from the well studied stock market case. Based on both the spot and futures pricing mechanisms, we have studied the hedging policies for secondary operators, which have been shown to significantly reduce the risk by using the real measurement based numerical simulations.
